intro: Iberis tenoreana proles petraea, commonly known as the rock iris, is a rare and endemic plant species native to the island of Sardinia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family and is characterized by its compact, low-growing habit and bright blue or violet flowers. The plant typically thrives in rocky and coastal environments, showcasing adaptations to harsh, saline conditions. Its foliage consists of basal leaves that are linear to oblanceolate in shape, often covered in a fine layer of white wax. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts in its native range.
